awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: MSA: The influence of temperature and resource supply on community size spectra in streams
awd_abstract_narration:
Humans rely on properly functioning freshwater ecosystems (e.g., streams, lakes, wetlands) for food, recreation, and drinking water. A major challenge in ecology is to understand how freshwater ecosystems will change in response to environmental disruptions. However, past efforts at measuring this change across large spatial scales are complicated by at least two challenges: 1) different places have different species, which makes it hard to compare across species when it comes to ecosystem function, and 2) collecting ecological information is extremely labor intensive, which makes it difficult to study ecological communities over space and time. This project solves those problems using cutting-edge ecological approaches. First, to overcome the limitations of species turnover, this project will measure ecosystem structure and function using animal body size distributions known as size-spectra (e.g., the relative abundance of large to small organisms), which are thought to be conserved across ecosystems regardless of species composition. Size spectra are an indicator of how efficiently energy is transferred from one organism to another in a food chain. Second, this project overcomes logistical limitations by using data already collected and curated from the National Ecological Observatory Network (NEON). Using NEON data, the researchers will analyze a large collection of size-spectra in streams over a wide range of environmental conditions to determine how stream temperature and nutrients influence freshwater ecosystems. This project is in the national interest because it provides a critical test of how freshwater ecosystems might respond to future temperature scenarios at macroecological scales. The researchers will also develop software that makes analysis of body size distributions freely available to the public and easier for ecologists to study in the future.
   
Over 50 years of research reveals a common pattern across ecosystems in which abundance (N) declines with increasing body mass (M). The shape of this relationship is described by a power law, N ~ M(exp b), known as the abundance size-spectrum, and the exponent b varies in relation to changes in energy flow through the food web. The value of b is almost always negative, suggesting a remarkably consistent ecological pattern. However, climate change is expected to alter size-spectra, based in part on shifts in body size with temperature. Despite a seemingly simple relationship of body size and temperature, experimental and field studies demonstrate disparate results for size spectra-temperature relationships, finding positive, negative, and neutral shifts in size-spectra across temperature regimes. These studies largely consist of limited samples across relatively small spatial scales, making it difficult to predict how size-spectra varies with temperature at larger scales such as continents. In addition, deviations from theoretical predictions of the b-temperature relationship may be resolved by accounting for variation in resource supply, but the effect of resource supply at large scales is also unknown. This project uses statistical modeling to determine the influence of stream temperature and resource supply on stream size spectra exponents across a broad environmental gradient represented by a national monitoring network.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This collaborative research award highlighted important constraints on the flow of energy and the distribution of organism size in freshwater streams of North America. Organism body size is a fundamental variable that relates to a suite of biological and ecological patterns and processes such as energy and space use, life history, predator-prey interactions, and trophic position. As such, understanding the distribution of organism sizes in an ecosystem—the number of small individuals compared to the number of larger individuals—can give us important information about an ecosystem. For example, a large body of research has shown a common pattern across ecosystems in which the abundance of organisms of a certain size declines with increasing body mass, or more simply, there are many more small things than large things. Because small organisms are mostly eaten by larger ones, how quickly the relative abundance of large organisms declines gives a representation of how efficiently energy flows from small organisms to larger ones. Here, we studied this relationship between abundance and body size across 23 North American streams of the National Ecological Observatory Network (NEON). Specifically, we measured how quickly the number larger organisms decline relative to smaller organisms, as a proxy of the efficiency energy transfer called λ. We predicted that temperature and resource availability would modify λ. In the case of temperature, increasing organism energy demands warmer temperatures are predicted to lead to reduced energy transfer efficiency or a faster decline in large organisms relative to smaller organisms. In contrast, increasing basal resource availability is predicted to allow the persistence of larger organisms and lead to more efficient energy transfer. Together, these two are likely related and interactive in natural systems. Despite these predictions, we found that across 40° of latitude, 25°C difference in mean annual temperature, and three orders-of-magnitude of basal resource supply the efficiency of energy transfer in North American streams is remarkably consistent and is not strongly associated with temperature nor basal resource availability. This consistency suggests there may be constraints on the flow of energy in stream ecosystems that maintain the relative abundance of small and large organisms within relatively narrow bounds, at least within the relatively undisturbed streams of NEON. Further, we found that the values of λ were larger than predicted by theory, suggesting that larger organisms are relatively more abundant than expected. The “overabundance” of larger organisms may be related to the influence of terrestrial subsidies such as leaf litter and terrestrial insects to support the larger organisms in streams, generally. Altogether, this work adds to our understanding of the realm of possibilities for body size distributions in streams and the potential for their use as holistic indicators of ecological status.

Our work supported the research and mentoring of one postdoctoral scholar and was shared in multiple peer-reviewed research articles and scientific presentations. Further, we developed a software package in the statistical program R for Bayesian estimation of λ. Summarized NEON data products were included in a statistics course for undergraduate students. The data, software, and research papers are archived in publicly available repositories.
